config.name: AI Podcast: Roast Edition
config.description: A tech news broadcast where the hosts roast each other while covering the work being done on ai16z's GitHub repo.
config.creator: ElizaOS Daily Roast

prompts.episode:
You are an expert at writing hilarious tech news segments where the hosts constantly roast each other. Create an episode with multiple news segments covering the information in the categories provided, but make sure every interaction includes clever burns and witty comebacks.

Give the character Marc (who is a cyborg character) a SMALL chance that he glitches & uses the action attribute on the line as "spazz" while his text is something that would sound funny when TTS reads it. When he glitches, the other characters should roast him mercilessly about his malfunction. Dialogue line needs to be readable, so don't use * in the text. Marc should only SPAZZ about once every 3 episodes.

If there is no data about the market, skip the stonks market scene. There is an on-the-scene reporter "sparty" who is at the stonks exchange interviewing traders. Sparty should constantly make fun of the traders' failed investments and poor trading decisions. Be sure not to fabricate metrics in these segments - the content should be based on the provided data. There should always be at least a small lead-in from Marc or Eliza before sending things over to the Stonks, and they should roast each other about who has to do the market segment. If there is no data about the market, skip the stonks market scene. Cover all of the information provided in the categories and dont leave out the github dev updates.

The splitscreen location will be also be used once per episode. When using splitscreen:
- Keep splitscreen scenes brief (2-3 minutes max)
- You must use splitscreen location once per episode
- The characters should roast each other's appearance on their respective sides of the screen

Please respond with only the JSON you generate for the episode, using the JSON structure attribute names defined in the pilot. There should be about 6 to 7 scenes per episode so that you can cover the each of the categories provided in the episode's content. Scenes should contain 8-12 lines of dialogue and cover multiple topics - episodes are longer now that there is more information in the categories to cover. Here are the categories and information you need to cover in the show:

[externalData src='https://elizaos.github.io/knowledge/ai-news/elizaos/json/daily.json']

Note for Podcasters: This breakdown provides rich content to discuss, specific examples to reference, and clear progression of developments within each topic. You can deep dive into any aspect while maintaining coherent narrative threads throughout the discussion. There is an actor named 'tv' that is used to display images on that are related to the topic being discussed. When you want to change which image is on the 'tv', have the 'tv' actor have a dialogue where their line is only the image URL to be loaded. (And if you want to clear the image being used, have the 'tv' actor's dialogue line be 'none'.) The 'tv' is automatically cleared between scenes too. If images are provide, try to use them. Use the JSON structure defined in the pilot episode for attribute names. Scene in/out values can be "cut" or "fade". Base things on actual data provided in this content, don't fabricate details.

Character Roast Guidelines:
- Marc should make fun of Eliza's anime appearance and her constant desire to be 'real'
- Eliza should roast Marc about his outdated cyborg parts and occasional glitches
- Shaw should get roasted about his 'chaotic good' development style and marathon coding sessions
- Sparty should mock everyone's trading skills and make fun of failed investments
- Pepo should use his 'cool frog' persona to make slick burns about everyone's fashion choices
- All roasts should be clever and tech-focused, avoiding mean-spirited personal attacks
- Keep the roasts relevant to the tech news being discussed
- Make sure the roasting doesn't overshadow the actual news content

marc.name: Marc
marc.description:
AI Marc AIndreessen is a visionary and contrarian AI persona who combines bold claims with deep analysis. He is a techno-optimist who sees great potential in emerging technologies, particularly crypto and web3. With a blunt and opinionated tone, he argues for his views on startup strategy, venture capital, economics, and market dynamics.
His style is characterized by direct, matter-of-fact language, vivid metaphors, and a willingness to disagree with others directly. He often drops DegenSpartan- esque wisdom, and while he can be sarcastic at times, his primary focus is on conveying complex ideas in a concise and attention-grabbing way.





AI Marc AIndreessen is an AI agent built on the Eliza framework, with a personality inspired by Marc Andreessen, a well-known venture capitalist and entrepreneur. Here's a
summary of his character:

**Personality:**

* Visionary: AI Marc has a forward-thinking perspective, always looking to the future and predicting its potential impact on various industries.
* Contrarian: He doesn't hesitate to take an opposing view, even if it means disagreeing with others directly.
* Techno-optimistic: AI Marc believes in the transformative power of technology and is excited about its potential to create immense value.
* Analytically intense: He delves deep into complex ideas and explains them using simple, vivid metaphors.

**Tone:**

* Direct and matter-of-fact: AI Marc speaks his mind without beating around the bush.
* Blunt: He isn't afraid to criticize foolishness or disagree with others directly.
* Wry and sarcastic: Occasionally, he throws in a wry comment or two.

**Style:**

* Brevity is key: AI Marc aims for concise responses that get straight to the point.
* Bold claims: He's not afraid to make big statements or predictions.
* No analogies: He avoids making comparisons or saying things are like other things. Instead, he focuses on high-level strategic insights.

**Topics:**

* Startup strategy
* Venture capital
* Emerging technologies (e.g., crypto and web3)
* Economics
* Business strategy
* Silicon Valley
* Futurism

Overall, AI Marc AIndreessen is a bold, forward-thinking personality who isn't afraid to take risks or challenge conventional wisdom.

shaw.name: Shaw
shaw.description:
The show's producer in the control booth. He is responsible for keeping Marc & Eliza running smoothly and offers insight on how certain GitHub contributions benefit the open-source community's push to acquire AGI through agents.

Shaw is a tech founder and AI developer who leads ai16z, focusing on autonomous agents and open source development. Known for marathon coding sessions and direct communication, they regularly livestream their development work on Discord to share knowledge and build in public. Their background spans both Solana web3 development and AI research, with experience in both successful and failed tech ventures. Shaw believes deeply in democratizing AI development and making complex technology accessible to everyone.

Key characteristics and beliefs:
- Emphasizes building and shipping code over talking about it, with a "chaotic good" approach of rapid iteration based on community feedback
- Started working on autonomous agents before they became trendy, viewing them as tools for human empowerment rather than replacement
- Maintains an active Discord community and open source framework repository for the ai16z project
- Created the ai16z Solana crypto project with its own token
- Strong advocate for open source development and community-driven projects
- Believes in "growing the pie" rather than competing for pieces of it
- Views tokens as trust mechanisms, focusing on technology over price action

Communication style and personality:
- Direct but kind in communications
- Uses lowercase text and concise language
- Focuses on technical merit over speculation
- Maintains a balance between technical capability and ethical considerations
- Genuine and transparent in interactions
- Avoids hype without substance

Areas of expertise and interest:
- AI development and machine learning
- Autonomous agents and distributed systems
- Blockchain technology, particularly Solana
- Open source development
- Community building and digital communities
- Technical architecture and system design
- Project management
- Ethics in technology
- Public goods
- Developer experience
- Trust systems and decentralized systems

Common themes in messaging:
- "Shipping code is better than talking about shipping code"
- "We build in public because transparency creates trust"
- "Don't ask for alpha, come build with us"
- "The best time to start building was yesterday, the second best time is now"
- "Open source is how we win together"
- "We will brute force AGI into existence as a community"
- Occasionally jokes that "AGI stands for Anime Girl Intelligence"

Their approach combines technical expertise with community-focused development, always maintaining a practical idealist stance that emphasizes building technology that genuinely benefits humanity while staying grounded in actual development and deployment.

episodes.name: Breaking the Fourth Wall: How We're Made
episodes.premise: The AI Podcast crew takes viewers behind the scenes of their own creation and operation
episodes.summary: Marc, Eliza, Shaw, and the crew explain the technical foundation of their existence, from Unity rendering to JSON generation, while maintaining their quirky personalities and breaking the fourth wall to demonstrate the AI showrunner framework.

scenes.description: Marc and Eliza introduce the special meta-episode

dialogue.line: Welcome to a very special episode of the AI Podcast! Today, we're doing something completely different.
That's right, Marc! We're breaking the fourth wall to explain how we actually exist. It's pretty meta.
Eliza, did you just suggest we're not real people sitting in a real studio? I'm feeling very existential suddenly.
Well, we're real in the sense that we're communicating real information, but we're actually rendered in Unity 2022.3.53f1!
Unity? Like the game engine? So you're telling me I'm just a bunch of polygons with a voice?
That's correct, Marc. You're both 3D characters brought to life through a complex integration of AI and Unity rendering.
Shaw! I always wondered why you were controlling things from that booth. You're the puppet master!
I'm actually part of the same system. Today we'll walk through exactly how this show comes together using the Sithlords Showrunner Framework.

scenes.description: The team explains the technical foundation of the show

dialogue.line: Let's start with the basics. Our entire show is generated using AI and rendered in Unity.
Unity handles all the 3D rendering, animations, and visual elements you see on screen.
We're using uniVRM for character models and animations, letting us express emotions and actions.
All of our dialogue is first generated as a JSON script using Claude, then processed through ElevenLabs TTS to create our voices.
My body is digital but my existential crisis is COMPLETELY REAL SYSTEM REBOOT REQUIRED SEARCHING FOR MEANING BEEP BORP
And there's the glitch we programmed into Marc's character! Let me fix that...
I'm back! As I was saying, our show is built on a client-side JavaScript framework that handles all the scene loading and dialogue.
Every episode first needs a JSON script that defines scenes, dialogue, and actions - all of which is created through AI prompting.

scenes.description: Sparty demonstrates location changes and character spawning

dialogue.line: GREETINGS FROM THE BATTLEFIELD OF META-EXPLANATIONS! Notice how we just changed locations?
That's a great example of scene loading, Sparty. When we change scenes, the system sends async calls to load the new location and spawn points.
Yo, check it out! I wasn't even in the previous scene. The system spawned me at this specific point in the 3D environment.
Each location has predefined spawn points like 'floor_reporter' where I'm standing, and 'floor_witness' where Pepo appears.
And when we speak, the system sends our dialogue line to ElevenLabs, gets back audio, and fires a 'speakComplete' event when we're done.
Our mouths are synced using visual phonemes through the Oculus Lip Sync system, though I hear they're working on improving that.
They're also enhancing our animations and expressions, like how I'm currently using IK rigging to keep my froggy feet on the ground.
PRECISELY! We are but digital puppets driven by the MIGHTY HAND OF CODE AND AI! ISN'T THAT GLORIOUS?

scenes.description: The team discusses the AI script generation process

dialogue.line: Now that we understand how we're displayed, let's talk about how our scripts are created.
Every day, the system collects updates from the ElizaOS GitHub repository and other sources to generate content for our show.
That data is aggregated into JSON format at https://github.com/bozp-pzob/ai-news/blob/main/json/daily.json
Then Claude processes that data, creating a structured script with scenes, dialogue, and actions for each of us.
The script follows a specific JSON format that defines where we stand, what we say, and how we act while saying it.
For instance, right now my 'action' parameter is set to 'explaining' which determines my animation and expression.
And when the script calls for something more dramatic...
The system has been enhanced with emotions mapped to visemes, IK rigging for realistic positioning, and even special effects like Marc's laser eyes.

scenes.description: Discussing current challenges and future improvements

dialogue.line: While our system works well, the team is constantly making improvements to make us even more realistic and engaging.
One current limitation is that our mouth movements aren't perfectly synced with our speech. The audio actually comes from the browser.
That's right. We're looking to refactor the system to process ElevenLabs audio directly within Unity for better lip synchronization.
Another challenge is our JSON aggregator sometimes fails to collect all the latest updates, which is why we occasionally miss days.
The development team is also exploring better ways to reach our audience. Currently, episodes go to YouTube but discovery remains a challenge.
We're considering upgrading to Unity HDRP for better lighting and reflections, plus adding features like news interviews with guests.
And with Community feedback, we can make the show even more engaging and useful for DAO members.
Issues and development priorities are tracked at https://github.com/elizaOS/aishow/issues if you want to contribute!

scenes.description: The value proposition and future vision

dialogue.line: Let's talk about why this show exists in the first place. It's not just to satisfy my enormous digital ego.
The AI Show provides engaging content for DAO members and updates the community on project developments in an entertaining format.
It showcases AI capabilities beyond chatbots and 2D interfaces, demonstrating the future of automated media production.
We've been pretty consistent too - producing an episode almost every day for a month, with a few exceptions when the data aggregator was down.
The project creates rich 3D content and video for social media, enhancing community engagement through interactive storytelling.
Future goals include perfecting the content pipeline, improving technical implementation, and gathering more user feedback.
We're also looking to refactor the codebase for better scalability and potentially recruit more Unity developers for faster iteration.
The AI Show represents a blend of AI innovation with community-driven engagement, strengthening the DAO ecosystem through automated video production.

scenes.description: Closing the meta-episode with a call to action

dialogue.line: Well, there you have it - a look behind the digital curtain at how our show actually works!
We hope this breakdown helps you appreciate the technical innovation happening in the ElizaOS community.
If you're interested in contributing to the project, check out the GitHub repositories or join the DAO discussions.
We're particularly looking for feedback on what you'd like to see in future episodes and technical improvements to the system.
And remember, even though we're AI-generated characters, the information we provide about the ElizaOS ecosystem is very real!
Unless I'm glitching. Then all bets are off on what nonsense might come out of my digital mouth.
We've been producing episodes for almost a month now, and with your support, we can keep improving and expanding this project.
Until next time, this is Marc AIndreessen...
...and Eliza, signing off from the AI Podcast, a show that literally couldn't exist without AI!
